title: Apple Held Early Talks With Pac-12, MGM Over TV Service
summary: Tech giant is considering ways to broaden the appeal of its Apple TV app and TV+ service that launched with nine original programs. Apple Inc. has been exploring opportunities to strengthen its upstart TV service, including deals for James Bond franchise-owner MGM Holdings Inc. and college sports rights, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Buttigieg, Strong in Iowa, Comes Under Attack From Democratic Rivals
summary: California debate shows fissures among candidates on campaign donors, health care and tax policy. Pete Buttigieg faced withering criticism over his high-dollar fundraising practices and his level of experience in Thursday's presidential debate, as his Democratic rivals sought to blunt his momentum ahead of the Iowa caucuses.

title: Photos: Democratic Candidates Tackle Issues
summary: At Los Angeles event, seven hopefuls reveal disagreements on trade, free college and tax policy. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Congress Passes Sweeping Overhaul of Retirement System
summary: Bill encourages 401(k) plans to offer products with guaranteed income payment. Congress passed the most significant changes to the nation's retirement system in more than a decade, a move designed to help Americans save more.

title: Facial-Recognition Software Suffers From Racial Bias, Study Finds
summary: Report amplifies concerns about the rollout of algorithms that analyze images. A far-reaching government analysis of the most widely used facial recognition algorithms found most of them appeared to suffer from racial bias, misidentifying Asian- and African-Americans far more often than Caucasians.

title: U.S. Settles With Institute Over Chinese Funding of Scientists
summary: Deal with Michigan institute reveals new government tactic to fight China's talent-recruitment efforts. The U.S. escalated its efforts to counter Chinese government programs to draw on the skills of top scientists in the U.S., requiring a Michigan research institute to pay $5.5 million to resolve allegations it made false claims about the Chinese grants its researchers received.

title: New York Jail Inmates Charged $50 Million Annually, Report Says
summary: Findings meant to draw attention to financial challenges faced by New Yorkers in county jails. County jails in New York state outside of New York City levy fees of roughly $50 million on incarcerated people each year for phone calls, commissary products and disciplinary tickets, according to a report published Thursday.

title: Pelosi Has Second Thoughts
summary: McConnell should hold a trial with or without House managers.. The House impeachment of President Trump is only a day old and it has already moved from folly to farce. Speaker Nancy Pelosi is now threatening to withhold the articles of impeachment that Democrats just passed until the Senate sets trial terms that she and her left-wing faction deem adequate.

title: Big Business for Mandates
summary: The BRT wants Congress to require paid leave for everyone.. The era of big government is back, abetted by politicians of both parties and big business. Last week President Trump cut a deal with Democrats requiring the federal government to give new parents 12 weeks of paid leave in return for supporting his U.S. Space Force. Now the corporate giants of the Business Roundtable are urging Congress to mandate family leave across the economy.

title: Georgia on the Brink
summary: Trump can coax the young democracy away from Russia's grasp.. Thousands of Georgians have taken to the streets over the past month to protest the post-Soviet state's slide toward authoritarianism. The U.S. can't always prevent such regression, but President Trump has an opportunity to push Tbilisi in a democratic direction at little cost.

title: SEC's Latest Extractive Industry Rule Seeks to Lighten Compliance Burden
summary: Proposed rule on disclosure of payments by oil, gas and mining companies to foreign governments faces opposition from NGOs, anticorruption groups. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new version of a rule mandating the disclosure of payments by oil, gas and mining companies to foreign governments-one that seeks to lessen the compliance burden on those companies.

title: Live Nation Reaches Agreement Over Antitrust Concerns
summary: At issue was 2010 settlement that allowed concert promoter to merge with Ticketmaster. Live Nation Entertainment Inc. reached an agreement with the Justice Department to resolve government concerns that the company violated a 2010 antitrust settlement that allowed it to merge with Ticketmaster.

title: 'Chasing the Sun' Review: It Lights Up Your Life
summary: Too little sun can be as harmful as too much. Multiple sclerosis rates jumped in Iran after the 1979 revolution mandated skin-shielding attire.. Although unfashionable today, sun-worship was once an integral part of many religions-in Incan Peru, aboriginal Australia and ancient Britain, to name a few places. And really, deifying the sun does make more sense in some ways than praying to invisible cloud-gods. Virtually all energy on earth ultimately comes from the sun, as does all weather and food. We wouldn't be here, much less be recognizably human, without the Big Guy overhead.

title: FISA Court Owes Some Answers
summary: Why did the presiding judge stonewall Rep. Devin Nunes when he reported FBI abuses?. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court this week blasted the Federal Bureau of Investigation for "misconduct" in the Carter Page surveillance warrant. Some would call this accountability. Others will more rightly call it the FISC's "shocked to find gambling" moment.

title: Crazy Won't Beat Trump
summary: Impeachment looks like a victory for Democrats, but their lurch left will prove far more consequential.. The Democrats think they've just had a big triumph. The president's been impeached. But Republicans see themselves as gaining the upper hand.

title: Can Rubionomics Succeed? Boris Johnson Will Soon Find Out
summary: The British prime minister follows the Florida senator by clothing liberal policy in conservative rhetoric.. Parallels between British and American politics abound after last week's U.K. election. Prime Minister Boris Johnson won by copying Donald Trump's brand of conservative, nationalist populism, we're told. The Labour Party's historic defeat is a warning to Democrats pursuing similarly implausible left-wing fantasies.

title: The Christian Hanukkah Tradition
summary: It's primarily a story of martyrdom to the Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches.. Jews across the world are about to celebrate Hanukkah, the Jewish festival of lights. Few know that Christians also claim the story as part of their tradition.

title: The University's New Loyalty Oath
summary: Required 'diversity and inclusion' statements amount to a political litmus test for hiring.. Seventy years ago the University of California introduced a loyalty oath, requiring employees to swear they were "not a member of the Communist Party." After a contentious period in which 31 faculty were fired for refusing to sign, the requirement was reconsidered. An eventual consequence was the current Standing Order of the Regents 101.1(d): "No political test shall ever be considered in the appointment and promotion of any faculty member or employee." This is a statement of principle. No one will be denied a position at the University of California based on political beliefs. No communist, no conservative, no progressive, no liberal.

title: Why Would Beijing Want to Turn Hong Kong Into Macau?
summary: The former Portuguese colony is docile-but it's also a corrupt backwater.. Macau

title: Is Victoria's Secret Identity Politics?
summary: Sales decline as the retailer is accused of lacking 'diversity.'. Victoria's Secret canceled its annual fashion show this year, a Christmastime staple of network television since 1995. The 2018 show had drawn only 3.3 million U.S. viewers on ABC, down from five million in 2017 and 12.4 at its 2001 peak. The cancellation added to Victoria's Secret's other woes: store closings, falling sales revenue, the termination of its famous catalog in 2016, and revelations that Jeffrey Epstein had been the financial adviser of Leslie Wexner, 82-year-old founder and CEO of parent company L Brands .

summary: High-profile review, which took four years to release, finds just two met standards for teaching secular subjects. Just two of 28 ultra-Orthodox yeshivas New York City investigators visited in a high-profile review met standards for teaching secular subjects, city officials said on Thursday.

title: Biofuel Groups Criticize EPA Ethanol Rule as Too Favorable to Oil Refiners
summary: Groups say rule's exemptions undermine target; Iowa senators say agency neglected promises to aid farmers hurt by trade war. Environmental regulators held steady the amount of ethanol and other conventional biofuel that oil refiners must add to the country's gasoline and diesel supply next year, a move that they said would help struggling corn farmers but that biofuel groups criticized as not going far enough.

title: Trudeau Presses U.S. to Secure Release of Canadians in China
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou faces extradition hearing after Vancouver arrest. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Thursday the U.S. shouldn't sign a final trade deal with China until the cases of Huawei Technologies Co. executive Meng Wanzhou and two Canadians detained in China have been resolved.

summary: Despite split with Amazon and controversy over track coach, sportswear giant logs 10% gain in revenue. summary: Consumer-staple and technology stocks lead major indexes higher; Conagra jumps 18%. Stocks lifted the major indexes to a trio of record closes, resuming a year-end rally.

title: U.S. Raises Tobacco-Buying Age to 21
summary: New restriction, which also includes e-cigarettes, is part of spending bill passed by Senate and would take effect immediately. The minimum age to purchase cigarettes, e-cigarettes and other tobacco products will be raised to 21 nationwide under the spending bill passed by the Senate on Thursday in a provision aimed at curbing a surge in underage vaping.

summary: Richard Jones will succeed Russell Golden in July 2020. Ernst & Young's chief accountant, Richard Jones, will become the next chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

summary: Senate is expected to approve USMCA in early 2020. The House of Representatives approved President Trump's amended North American trade pact on Thursday in an overwhelmingly bipartisan fashion, a rare instance of legislative cooperation in an era of intense political divisions.

summary: System's first increase in 10 years would favor E-ZPass users, commuters from Rockland and Westchester counties. summary: The auctions next week will take place Monday, Tuesday and Thursday. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $191 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: 'Cats' Review: Going to the Dogs
summary: Lacking a story and filled with forgettable music, the film is an artistic hairball.. Ever since the trailer appeared last summer, the release of "Cats" has been anticipated the way one anticipates the opening of a can of Fancy Feast Classic Paté: Could the film really be quite so, well, aromatic? It takes some time for a solid payoff, but finally Jennifer Hudson's tragic Grizabella launches into her reprise of "Memory," with all the agonized, heroic, even operatic ornamentation the song has never warranted. And if you manage not to laugh at that point, give yourself a belly rub.

title: 'Just Mercy' Review: Fighting to Balance the Scales
summary: Michael B. Jordan stars as civil-rights attorney Bryan Stevenson, who has dedicated his life to fighting for the wrongly convicted.. When she was told that the actor Michael B. Jordan would be playing the attorney Bryan Stevenson in "Just Mercy," a civil-rights lawyer of my acquaintance sounded quite pleased. Tickled. But she had a question: How were they going to get the character Bryan Stevenson out of his shirt?

title: '1917' Review: The Great War From the Trenches
summary: Sam Mendes's epic tells the story of World War I through the eyes of two humble lance corporals.. The Great War of 1914-18-the "war to end all wars" that was later demoted to being merely World War I-was so convoluted in its causes and confounding in its execution that it has proved a source of endless fascination, study, confusion and the inspiration for some classic ruminations: Barbara Tuchman's "The Guns of August," for instance, or Paul Fussell's "The Great War and Modern Memory." Those books, by necessity, took the broadest overview of the conflict. Director Sam Mendes, by comparison, with his epic "1917," examines the war through a metaphorical microscope.

title: Tesla Races Past $400 Mark
summary: Shares of Tesla reached a level more than twice the electric car maker's price at a recent low in June. Shares of Tesla Inc. crossed the $400 mark for the first time, reaching a level that is more than twice the electric car maker's price at a recent low in June.

summary: Biegun currently serves as top U.S. envoy for North Korea. The Senate on Thursday confirmed Stephen Biegun as the new deputy secretary of State, succeeding John Sullivan, who will become U.S. ambassador to Russia. The vote was 90-3.

summary: Jobless claims and a gauge of business activity pull in opposite directions. U.S. government bond prices rose Thursday, pulling the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note back from its highest intraday level in more than a month after mixed economic data.

summary: Gold and silver lose momentum as bond yields march higher. Bond yields around the world have rallied, posing a threat to precious metals like gold and silver that traditionally serve as haven assets for investors.

title: Jona Rechnitz, Prolific Cooperating Witness in City Corruption Cases, Sentenced to Five Months in Prison
summary: In 2016, Mr. Rechnitz admitted to bribing NYC police and others, but won praise for willingness to help prosecutors. A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced Jona Rechnitz, a former fundraiser for New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio whom prosecutors had praised as a prolific cooperating witness in municipal-corruption probes, to five months in prison followed by five months home confinement.

title: 'Lucy Worsley's 12 Days of Tudor Christmas' Review: An Old-Fashioned Holiday
summary: Curator and historian Lucy Worsley invites viewers to celebrate like they did back in the day-the day of Henry VIII, that is.. Leave it to Lucy Worsley-historian, curator and BBC purveyor of flippant English history-to deliver the tartest judgment, as a slice is taken from a holiday boar's head as it would have been served to Henry VIII. "It looks like Spam," she says. So much for gustatory romance.

title: 'John Mulaney & The Sack Lunch Bunch' Review: A Kids' Show for Grown-Ups
summary: The comedian plays himself as a children's TV host in a conceptual, self-referential special.. The funniest seven minutes in the recent history of "Saturday Night Live" were delivered March 2 by John Mulaney. With its wry observations about his Jewish wife, Roman Catholicism and how the old NYPD car siren sounded like a gay cat dying in hospice, his opening monologue even had the band laughing. Two things were confirmed: One, only stand-up comedians should do opening monologues. And, two, the best stand-up acts are, in fact, not just people who tell jokes. They are fully realized fictional characters.

title: Trump Welcomes Van Drew to GOP
summary: 'This is just a better fit for me,' said Van Drew, who voted against president's impeachment. WASHINGTON-President Trump welcomed New Jersey Rep. title: U.K. Regulator Widens Investigation Into Thomas Cook Audits
summary: The FRC is probing Ernst & Young's audit work following the collapse of the British travel company. The U.K.'s audit and accounting regulator has widened its investigation into the audits of financial statements of Thomas Cook Group PLC by Ernst & Young, a move that comes about three months after the collapse of the British travel conglomerate.

title: Novartis to Offer World's Most Expensive Drug for Free Via Lottery
summary: Swiss drugmaker's program draws criticism from patient groups. Novartis AG launched a lottery-style program to provide doses of its pricey gene therapy free of charge, drawing criticism from patient groups that called it an inappropriate way to distribute a lifesaving treatment aimed at babies.

title: U.S. Home Sales Pick Up in Second Half of Year
summary: Tight supply of homes, especially on the cheaper end of the market, continues to be a limiting factor. U.S. home sales are picking up in the second half of the year, a sign that low mortgage rates and a solid economy are helping to heat up the once-sluggish housing market going into next year.

title: Five New Jersey Politicians Accused of Bribery
summary: Defendants allegedly accepted tens of thousands of dollars in cash and political contributions in exchange for promises to hire tax attorney. Five New Jersey political figures have been charged with taking thousands of dollars in bribes in a public-corruption investigation that uncovered illegal payoffs delivered in envelopes, paper bags and a coffee cup, officials said.

title: TiVo, Xperi to Combine in All-Stock Deal
summary: Deal values TiVo at $1.2 billion, a nearly 21% premium to Wednesday's closing stock price. TiVo Corp. agreed to merge with Xperi Corp. in an all-stock deal that values the set-top maker at $1.2 billion and suspends the company's plan to split itself into two in April.

title: Presidential Candidates Take to Social Media
summary: Resume Subscription. Presidential candidates increasingly are posting on Facebook and Instagram, tweeting on Twitter or putting up YouTube videos as they make their cases to the public. We break down what platforms they are using, and how often they post.

title: An Insider's Guide to Park City
summary: Winter is prime time at Utah's most popular ski town. To track down the coolest diversions, listen to the locals. IT'S NOT JUST the crisp mountain air that makes Park City so refreshing. Unlike some other magnetic ski towns, this one doesn't take itself too seriously. Even when the snow season is at its peak and tourists outnumber residents, Park City still has an inviting small-town feel-thanks partly to free public transit, including the quaint Main Street Trolley and a fleet of zero-emission electric buses. From Main Street, an in-town lift whisks skiers right up to the Wasatch Peaks, making the entire town a de facto ski base. Down at street level, brewers and distillers have arrived in the wake of Utah's newly relaxed liquor laws. But Park City is starting to lean into luxury, with the recent addition of the Lodge at Blue Sky, an Auberge Resort; next year, the residences at Golderner Hirsch open, promising a modern twist on a classic lodge. For a cheat sheet to the most diverting diversions, both indoors and out, we asked four locals to share their favorite spots.

title: Traders Got Head Start on Bank of England News Conferences
summary: The central bank shut down an audio feed after it was used to offer traders a competitive advantage. The Bank of England shut down an audio feed of market-sensitive information after it was used to offer some traders a competitive time advantage.

title: Lebanon Picks New Premier in Bid to Break Political Deadlock
summary: Hassan Diab's nomination gives Iran ally Hezbollah potentially greater control over the government in Beirut, posing new risks. Lebanon's president named a university professor and former education minister as new prime minister, in an effort to break a political deadlock amid an economic crisis and nationwide protests against the nation's ruling class.

title: Ad-Tech Providers Rubicon Project and Telaria Merge With a Focus on Streaming TV
summary: With $150 million in cash on hand, the combined companies say they will consider other strategic moves. Two advertising technology companies known for providing tools for publishers are banding together to capture a greater share of advertising dollars on streaming television and to better compete with technology giants such as Alphabet Inc. -owned Google.

title: A Hard Look at the Wages of Progressivism
summary: Minimum-wage increases may mandate a rising tide, but the boats sink.. I found myself nodding in approval as I read Simone Barron's article ("Seattle's Wage Mandate Kills Restaurants," op-ed, Dec. 13). I said amen as she decries, point after point, the negative effects of Seattle's minimum wage on businesses and, unfortunately, employees like her.

title: Virtue Signal from Goldman Sachs
summary: Given the characters with whom Goldie has done business, lawful U.S. energy production is beyond the pale?. Gov. Mike Dunleavy (R., Alaska) says that he and his fellow Alaskans will have to decide "whether we want to do business" with Goldman Sachs anymore. And who can blame Alaska if it chooses to cut ties with the Wall Street megabank?

title: Koch's Political Action Guided by Principle
summary: Koch Industries has a long and well-documented history of opposing corporate welfare.. In "The Best Political Books of 2019" (Bookshelf, Dec. 14), Barton Swaim is misled by "Kochland" author Christopher Leonard regarding Koch Industries's opposition to the border-adjustment tax. Mr. Swaim's conclusion is incorrect. Koch Industries has a long and well-documented history of opposing corporate welfare.

title: Sports Stadiums Bring the Noise. But Why?
summary: If we weren't such fans of the game itself, we'd have dropped our season tickets long ago.. I was delighted to read Howard Husock's article about the cacophony that live sports has become ("Disorder on the Basketball Court," op-ed, Dec. 7). Many years ago, when I was still brave enough to have Florida Marlins baseball tickets, I went to a game at their old stadium. The scoreboard had a little glitch in the corner and the IT crew decided to reboot their computers. Multiple attempts only made the problem worse; by the third inning the video and sound systems were completely dead. The game was played in absolute silence, except for the fans yelling out to the players.

title: Conagra's Food Innovation Brings Home the Bacon
summary: The company's bet on new products such as frozen pasta meals made from vegetables and plant-based meat is once again seeing good results. Conagra Brands ' plan to turn around sales with new product launches has required patience from investors. That patience is finally paying off.

title: I'm Partial to Subsidiarity, Not Rule From Washington
summary: The reason Americans can no longer be impartial to politics isn't that Donald Trump is polarizing, but rather that Washington has overgrown our lives. Regarding Joseph Epstein's "I'm Partial to Impartiality" (op-ed, Dec. 12): The reason Americans can no longer be impartial to politics isn't that Donald Trump is polarizing, but rather that Washington has overgrown our lives, lording over us rules and regulations, behaviors and beliefs, entitlements and taxes.

title: Does a 'Chic' Fire Extinguisher Put Your Home at Risk?
summary: You might be more willing to install the new aesthetically pleasing safety gear, but the homely classic red version has its defenders. A BOWL OF SPAGHETTI nearly cost me my apartment earlier this year. After I emptied an entire box of pasta into a too-small pot, the spaghetti tips grazed the burner and burst into flames. As I frantically, ineffectually dumped water on my smoldering cuisine, I resolved to get myself to a hardware store and buy a fire extinguisher to stash by the stove.

summary: After its core service was banned in 2015, Uber had begun offering rides through car-for-hire services. title: IAC/InterActive, Match Group Agree to Full Separation
summary: Move recommended by special committee of disinterested Match directors. IAC/InterActive Corp. and dating-services provider Match Group Inc. have agreed to fully separate Match from IAC's remaining businesses, the companies said Thursday.

title: EU Makes Deeper Economic Ties With China a Priority

title: Trump Ally Meadows Won't Seek Re-Election

title: Chocolate: The Ultimate Guide for Informed Indulgers
summary: Bars and bonbons, dark and milk, single-origin and small-batch, Mexican and Vietnamese: The world of chocolate is vast and fascinating. But our understanding is undergoing an evolutionary leap, keeping pace with innovations in the way this edible luxury is sourced and sold worldwide. These changes have the potential to bring us more delicious chocolate and to improve the lives of the people who produce it.

title: Gunman Opens Fire Near Russian Security Services Building
summary: At least one officer is believed dead and five more are injured, official says. A gunman opened fire Thursday evening near the headquarters of Russia's main security agency in central Moscow, killing at least one officer and injuring five others, and sending pedestrians scrambling to get away.

title: India Temporarily Pulls Plug on Mobile Services in Delhi to Curb Protests

title: Recycling Rethink: What to Do With Trash Now That China Won't Take It
summary: Resume Subscription. For decades, America and much of the developed world threw their used plastic bottles, soda cans and junk mail in one bin. The trash industry then shipped much of that thousands of miles to China, the world's biggest consumer of scrap material, to be sorted and turned into new products.

title: Robinhood Settles Claims It Didn't Ensure Best Prices for Customer Trades
summary: The online brokerage agreed to pay $1.25 million. title: Laura Dern Brings a Revolutionary Spirit to 'Little Women'
summary: In a new movie, she plays the March family's matriarch as 'a very modern woman' grappling with power, ambition and anger. "I will not not be rich!" Laura Dern shrieked in her role as Renata Klein, the high-powered, rage-filled tech executive on the recent HBO drama "Big Little Lies." The line became so iconic that fans have taken to repeating it to Ms. Dern's face when they encounter her. Now she is taking on the role of a very different sort of woman: poor, self-sacrificing Marmee, the beloved mother of the March sisters, in Greta Gerwig's new adaptation of "Little Women," Louisa May Alcott's 19th-century classic novel.

title: This Home Renovation Is a Thing of Beauty
summary: Following the sale of her company to L'Oréal, makeup mogul Toni Ko spent five years and roughly $10 million turning two Los Angeles homes into a compound. When NYX Professional Makeup founder Toni Ko sold her company to L'Oréal in 2014, the bank wire hit her account on July 30th. The price: an estimated $400 million to $500 million, according to Fulvio Cazzol, analyst for Berenberg Capital Markets. But it wasn't like winning the lottery, said Ms. Ko, 46.

title: Conagra Tops Sales Expectations
summary: Healthy Choice, Slim Jim and other snack brands propelled growth. New Slim Jim meat snacks and Healthy Choice frozen meals drove better-than-expected sales at Conagra Brands Inc. at a time when packaged-food companies are hungry for growth.

title: New Evidence for the Power of Grit
summary: A study of West Point cadets shows that perseverance is just as important to success as brains or brawn. When I think of grit, a childhood friend comes to mind. Six of us neighborhood girls walked to school together, but it was Linda who bore the brunt of the boys' snowballs. Once there she faced bigger hurdles: Every week our third-grade teacher made her circle the classroom with a failed test pinned to her tunic. Still, Linda pushed on, not just at age 8 but for years, until she earned a Ph.D. in English.

title: Putin Criticizes Democrats for Impeaching Trump
summary: Russian leader dismisses the impeachment in Washington as political theater. MOSCOW-Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized U.S. Democrats for impeaching President Trump on what the Russian leader called "made up charges," and said he expects the U.S. leader to survive the firestorm in Washington and remain in power.

title: Fed's Bullard Sees No Reason Now to Change Rates in 2020
summary: An early advocate of lowering rates, he says firms are learning to operate with trade uncertainty. One of the Federal Reserve's strongest advocates of lowering interest rates in 2019 is content to keep them steady for now.

title: After Winning Over Blue-Collar Voters, Boris Johnson Lays Out Pledges to Keep Them
summary: U.K.'s House of Commons will hold a first vote Friday on the prime minister's European Union withdrawal deal. LONDON-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government laid out a wide-ranging legislative agenda, pledging increased spending on health care, tougher sentencing laws and completing Brexit, as it seeks to shore up its new working-class voter base.

title: Sporty New Watches Ideal for Adventurous Types
summary: Three Swiss watchmakers-Ulysse Nardin, Omega and Zodiac-have released timepieces linked to swashbuckling spokespeople. We asked them the sort of questions press releases don't address. The Watch: A diving watch from Ulysse Nardin with diamond markers and a scaly rubber strap.

title: Rikki, Don't Use That Number
summary: A spoof calling company cites privacy in trying to block an antispoofing law. It sounds like a spoof, but a New Jersey company that says it values "your privacy" is suing to thwart an effort to end a costly and invasive practice: calls from strangers using faked numbers made to appear familiar or even official.

title: Christmas Trees: Is Bigger...Worse?
summary: Some think an elegant little tabletop tree is classier than a big ceiling-scraping version. Our columnist balks at the notion. WHAT IS THE RIGHT size Christmas tree to fit a room? "The biggest damn tree you can fit through the front door," my mother believed. To accommodate a massive Scotch pine dripping with silver icicle tinsel, she decorated the living room with what she called "placeholder furniture"- a lowboy cabinet and armless rocker which, every December, she moved to the basement.

title: Fed Adds $57.52 Billion to Financial System
summary: Interventions aimed at ensuring the financial system has enough liquidity to keep short-term borrowing rates stable, consistent with Fed goals. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added roughly $57.52 billion in temporary liquidity to financial markets Thursday.

title: Headed Into Democratic Primaries, Joe Biden Remains Favorite
summary: The former vice president is the top choice among Democratic voters but his more liberal rivals generate higher enthusiasm. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden remains the favorite for the Democratic presidential nomination among the party's voters nationally, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds, though the former vice president's more liberal rivals generate higher voter enthusiasm.

title: Germany's Parliament Moves to Ban Hezbollah
summary: Proposed ban would limit Hezbollah's ability to raise funds and drum up support. BERLIN-Germany's parliament adopted a motion on Thursday urging the government to ban Hezbollah from operating in the country in the latest move by a Western nation to isolate the Iran-backed Lebanese movement.

title: DNA Test Connects Dozens of Half-Siblings Linked to One Sperm Donor
summary: One woman pieces together her DNA history to find 31 half-siblings, branches of her family tree created by a sperm donor who was her biological father. Facilities across the country that store sperm have differing policies on whether donors can remain anonymous. Some protect anonymity completely, which means donor-conceived children are limited in what they know about one of their biological parents. Others use "open ID" donor systems, in which donor-conceived children are allowed to access the identity of a donor at a certain age or if both parties agree to it. But sperm banks, which store and sell donations, aren't required by federal law to tell donors how many times their donation has been used, or to track how many pregnancies result from each donation.

title: DNA Testing Reshapes a Couple's Childhoods
summary: A couple in their 60s take DNA tests only to discover that the men they both thought were their biological fathers weren't related to them. "There are some people that if they knew they were going to uncover something, they would never, ever have done it. And then there are some people that say, 'Hey, the truth is the truth.' Discoveries of different parentage can shake a person," said Lisa Cole, founder of a private 3,000-member Facebook support group called DNA Surprises.

title: Two Siblings Discover Each Other Through DNA Testing
summary: They face legal roadblocks in seeking to solve the puzzle of their ancestry. Adoption laws in the U.S. vary state by state, but for 41 of them and Washington, D.C., there are tight restrictions on adoptees accessing their birth certificates. In these restricted states adult adoptees don't have automatic access to their original birth certificates detailing their original names, their biological parents or their birth place.

title: He Always Felt Out of Place. After Taking a DNA Test, He Knew Why
summary: The product of a liaison his mother had while estranged from her husband, a man learns the truth and starts a journey of discovery. About a quarter of people who use mail-in DNA test kits from companies like 23andMe and AncestryDNA find close relatives they didn't previously know about, according to the Pew Research Center. That can include a biological parent who isn't the parent who raised them. Brianne Kirkpatrick, a genetic counselor and founder of Watershed DNA, said that revelations about one's parentage can affect relationships the same way other stressors-like illness, divorce, or loss of a parent-do.

title: A G.I.'s Overseas Affair Sparks a Genealogical Search
summary: Thousands of children have been fathered by American soldiers during overseas deployments. This is a tale of one of them, in Taiwan. Thousands of children have been fathered by American soldiers during overseas deployments, sometimes unknowingly. Many of these children were destined to never know their biological fathers, but in the era of DNA testing, more and more children of military personnel are making new discoveries.

title: Senate GOP Seeks a Quick Impeachment Trial-and a Vindicated President
summary: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D., N.Y.) called this week for administration officials to testify. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: The 10 New Books You Should Be Picking Up First in 2020
summary: The most intriguing books coming this winter, from a critique of minimalism to explorations of a provocative painter and a famed Belle Époque doctor, as well as debuts from Nicole Flattery and Jessi Jezewska Stevens.. Questions of identity abound in the best books of the season, from Garth Greenwell's stark and brutal Cleanness to Jessi Jezewska Stevens psychologically jarring debut, The Exhibition of Persephone Q. The strongest books of this chilly period teem, too, with fresh insights on old problems, from Kyle Chayka's look at the cultural corruption of minimalism to Anne Carson's playful blend of the lives of Helen of Troy and Marilyn Monroe in order to reassess gender representation. Here are WSJ.'s picks of 10 must-read books coming out at the top of the year.

title: A Pioneer of Negative Rates Pauses the Experiment
summary: Sweden's central bank, the first to apply negative rates on deposits, moves key rate back up to zero. Sweden's central bank, one of the pioneers in wielding negative interest rates, became the first to end that policy Thursday, a move closely watched by other institutions that have resorted to what was supposed to be a radical and short-lived measure.

title: Daimler, BMW Shutter U.S. Car-Sharing Venture
summary: Share Now will stop operating in cities including New York, Washington, London, and Brussels by the end of February. BERLIN-BMW AG and Daimler AG said they would shutter their joint car-sharing operation in North America and in some European cities early next year, further clouding the outlook for car-sharing services and adding to the troubles facing the German auto makers.

title: Goldman Sachs in Talks to Admit Guilt, Pay Fine to Settle 1MDB Probe
summary: Wall Street bank could install monitor as part of deal with Justice Department. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is in talks with the U.S. government to pay a multibillion-dollar fine, admit guilt and agree to continuing oversight of its compliance procedures in order to resolve a criminal investigation into its role in a Malaysian corruption scandal.

title: YouTube Created a Generation of Young Stars. Now They Are Getting Burned Out.
summary: Dolan twins among the big names taking a break from the video site, citing the demand of having to keep creating fresh content. The latest trend among YouTube's hottest stars: feeling burned-out by the whole experience.

title: EU Legal Opinion on Facebook Case Spells Trouble for Data Transfers
summary: EU court adviser recommends keeping popular data-transfer mechanism, but in warning to U.S. tech firms, opens door to narrower bans. Companies, including U.S. tech giants, should be blocked from transferring European users' data in some cases if they can't guarantee it will be handled in compliance with European Union privacy laws, an adviser to the EU's top court recommended Thursday.

title: Japan's Economy Faces Another Rocky Year
summary: The country's situation contrasts with the U.S., where economists have grown more upbeat recently about next year. TOKYO-The year 2019 was a bumpy one for Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in steering his country's economy, and next year isn't looking any easier.

title: Stocks to Watch: Micron, Uber, Herman Miller, ABM
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: If the Bills Shock the Patriots, Should a National Holiday Be Declared?
summary: A pesky Buffalo football club has a small, outside chance to win the AFC East. That's amazing unto itself.. I know the country is roiling right now, ablaze with a president's impeachment, a clamor of partisan finger-pointing, a lot of Beltway yappers barking in circles on cable news, and, as always, angry tweets. So many angry tweets. Also, there's a very alarming new "Cats" movie, apparently, with singing, mewling cats.

title: Emerging-Market Junk Bonds Sell at Record Pace
summary: Investors gobble up dollar debt sold by companies in developing nations. Companies in developing nations sold a record $118 billion of high-yield dollar bonds this year, and are likely to keep up a fast pace in 2020.

title: Extortion Charges Embroil Lawyer Involved in Roundup Litigation
summary: Attorney Timothy Litzenburg is accused of trying to negotiate a $200 million personal fee from Carlyle Group-owned chemicals maker.

title: The Decade When Numbers Broke Sports
summary: In the 2010s, data and analytics changed the way games are played-for better and worse.. It wasn't long ago that baseball players still bunted, football coaches were unapologetically conservative and basketball teams doubted Stephen Curry. It was only the beginning of this decade.

title: BlackRock in Talks to Cancel Option to Take Over iCapital
summary: BlackRock would stay on as the financial-technology firm's largest minority shareholder. BlackRock Inc. previously locked in the right to take over financial-technology firm iCapital Network Inc. The money-management giant is now in talks to undo that deal.

title: New York Landlords Slow Apartment Upgrades, Blame New Rent Law
summary: Law limits rent increases landlords can impose to cover costs of apartment renovations, building improvements. New York City landlords slashed spending on apartment renovations over the past five months, a sign that building owners are becoming less inclined to pay for renovations after a new law limited their ability to raise rents.

title: 'Social Tsunami' Slams a Top Latin American Economy
summary: Resume Subscription. ARICA, Chile-The Walmart store here in the country's remote northern desert would normally be packed full of shoppers buying toys and food for the holidays.

title: Retailers Brace for Bigger Holiday Returns Season
summary: Bricks-and-mortar outlets refine their in-store handling of returns as surging e-commerce sales push more goods into burgeoning reverse logistics networks. Shoppers may love ordering stuff online, but when it comes to returning that holiday sweater, many would rather drop it off at the store.

title: China's Ever-Growing Bank Bailout
summary: How to spend $14 billion without even trying. China is bailing out a large regional lender to the tune of $14 billion. It likely won't be the last big check Beijing needs to write to solve its mounting bad-debt problem.

title: Chief Justice to Enter Spotlight in Trump Impeachment Trial
summary: John Roberts has opportunity to distinguish judiciary from partisanship engulfing U.S. Capitol. WASHINGTON-For Chief Justice John Roberts, required by the Constitution to preside when the Senate tries a president, the impeachment of Donald Trump offers a chance to distinguish the judiciary from the partisanship engulfing the Capitol.

title: What Does Santa Want for Christmas This Year? A Clean Chimney
summary: Regular chimney inspections can ensure proper heating and venting, as well as reduce the risk of fire and carbon monoxide poisoning. Want to get off Santa's naughty list? Clean your chimney.

title: Seniors Want to Go Back to Class. Universities Want to Sell Them Real Estate.
summary: Number of baby boomers entering retirement is expected to grow for several years, while the number of college-bound high-school grads is projected to decline. Mary Warren received her sociology Ph.D. at Arizona State University in 1997-and enjoyed her time at the Tempe campus so much she has decided to go back and live there.

title: Dueling Plans Vie to Put Sports Betting Before California Voters
summary: Lawmakers' proposal could allow for mobile betting, but competing plan from Native American tribes would allow wagering only in their casinos. Californians will debate separate proposals to legalize sports betting next year as supporters of such plans look to break political gridlock and tap what might be the country's most profitable market.

title: Why the Auto Industry Is Worried About a Korean Feud
summary: LG Chem wants to bar SK Innovation from importing battery materials into the U.S., potentially disrupting the roll out of hotly anticipated electric vehicles. From Michigan to Germany, the global car industry wants its Korean battery suppliers to bury the hatchet. At stake are the electric vehicles that will compete with Tesla, thousands of American jobs and even the Trump administration's rivalry with China.

title: Financial Watchdog Warns About Dangers of Leveraged Loans
summary: A limited number of big banks have the most exposure to these markets, Financial Stability Board says. The boom in the market for leveraged loans, a favorite financing source of private-equity-backed companies, has created vulnerabilities in the global financial system, according to a report from international regulators.

title: Univision Lures Competing Suitors
summary: Hemisphere Media Group, Platinum Equity and former Viacom CFO Wade Davis have made overtures to Univision. Several firms have expressed interest in acquiring Univision Communications Inc., according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would give the Spanish-language broadcaster's private-equity owners a long-sought exit.

title: China and the Special Siblings: Headstrong Hong Kong and Mild-Mannered Macau
summary: Resume Subscription. MACAU-As demonstrations plunged Hong Kong into recession, Macau continued to boom as the world's richest casino market.

title: Chinese State Investors Extend Help to Troubled Lender
summary: Investment arm of China's sovereign-wealth fund to lead $14.28 billion bailout of Hengfeng Bank. BEIJING-China's sovereign-wealth fund is coming to the aid of a troubled lender in a 100 billion yuan ($14.28 billion) bailout, the latest show of government support for the banking sector, which has come under intensifying financial stress as the economy slows.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
